elements.content: Two novel new rigid tripodal arene core based nitrogen ligands, 1,3,5-tris(pyrazol-1-yl) benzene (L) and 1,3,5-tris[p-(pyrazol-1-yl)phenyl]benzene (L), have been synthesized. Self-assembly of L1 with silver(I) salts generated two three-dimensional porous supramolecular networks, {[Ag3L1 2X2]X} n (1 , X = ClO4 -; 2, X = NO3 -), with a common (10,3)-a topology. L2 reacts with silver nitrate, resulting in a one-dimensional chain which constructs a three-dimensional supramolecular network, {[Ag4L2 2(NO3)4]·2CH3OH} n (3), via hydrogen bonds. Three complexes have been structurally characterized. The anion exchanges were determined by IR spectroscopy, elemental analyses, and X-ray powder diffraction for complexes 1 and 2; the counteranions located in the cationic frameworks can be exchanged reversibly without destruction of the structures. This observation demonstrates that 1 and 2 can act as zeolite-like porous materials for anion exchange. The photoluminescent properties of 1,3,5-tris[p-(pyrazol-1-yl)phenyl]benzene and its silver complex 3 have been investigated; the results indicate that the intensity of the photoluminescent emission of the ligand can be influenced by coordination with silver ion. The influence of the ligand structure on the formation of the supramolecular construction is discussed.

Self-assembly of L1 with silver(I) salts generated two three-dimensional porous supramolecular networks, {[Ag3L1 2X2]X} n  (1 , X = ClO4 -; 2, X = NO3 -), with a common (10,3)-a topology. L2 reacts with silver nitrate, resulting in a one-dimensional chain which constructs a three-dimensional supramolecular network, {[Ag4L2 2(NO3)4]⋅2CH3OH} n  (3), via hydrogen bonds. Three complexes have been structurally characterized. The anion exchanges were determined by IR spectroscopy, elemental analyses, and X-ray powder diffraction for complexes 1 and 2; the counteranions located in the cationic frameworks can be exchanged reversibly without destruction of the structures. This observation demonstrates that 1 and 2 can act as zeolite-like porous materials for anion exchange. The photoluminescent properties of 1,3,5-tris[p-(pyrazol-1-yl)phenyl]benzene and its silver complex 3 have been investigated; the results indicate that the intensity of the photoluminescent emission of the ligand can be influenced by coordination with silver ion. The influence of the ligand structure on the formation of the supramolecular construction is discussed.

The photoluminescent emission intensity of the ligand can be influenced by coordination with silver ion. elements.content: Construction of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted great attention1 from chemists in recent years, owing to the new construction topologies available and their useful properties in applications such as adsorption, guest exchange, catalysis and chiral separation, magnetic materials, and optical properties. Considerable progress has been achieved in controlling the assembly of individual building blocks into structures with specific topologies and functions. Some structures of MOFs can, to a certain extent, be predicted by exploiting rigid organic ligands, second building units, and elaborately chosen metal salts to control the coordination geometry. However, it is still a challenge to predict the exact structure of assembly products, since the structure is controlled not only by the coordination geometry of the metal ions, the counteranions, the metal-to-ligand ratio, and the solvent system but also by the structural characteristics of polydentate organic ligands. Hence, systematic research on this subject is crucial in understanding the control of structure and topology of MOFs. Among the several factors dominating the design and synthesis of MOFs, it is of great importance to select suitable multidentate ligands. Tripodal ligands with nitrogen donors are a good choice for the construction of supramolecular structures with specific topologies such as individual cagelike structures, dumbbells, and three-dimensional MOFs. For example, rigid or flexible tripodal ligands such as 1,3,5-tricyanobenzene, 1,3,5-tris(4-ethynylbenzonitrile)benzene, 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoate, 1,3,5-tris(p-2,2‘-dipyridylamino)phenylbenzene, 1,3,5-tris(1-imidazolyl)-benzene, 1,3,5-tribenzimidazolyl-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene, 1,3,5-tris[(pyrazol-1-yl)methyl]-2,4,6-triethylbenzene, 1,3,5-tris(4-pyridylmethyl)benzene, and 1,3,5-tris[(benzimidazol-1-yl)methyl]-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene23 have been employed to generate supramolecular structures with metal salts. In contrast to the multiple coordination modes of the flexible tripodal ligands due to their flexibility and low symmetry, which allow the ligands to adopt different conformations according to the geometric needs of different metal ions, the rigid tripodal ligands may have fewer possible coordination modes. According to this approach, we now expand this system with another two novel tripodal ligands, 1,3,5-tris(pyrazol-1-yl)benzene (L1) and 1,3,5-tris[p-(pyraol-1-yl)phenyl]benzene (L2), and silver salts. Three supramolecular networks were obtained and structurally characterized, and the anion exchange properties and fluorescence properties of the complexes were investigated.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Construction of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted great attention1 from chemists in recent years, owing to the new construction topologies available and their useful properties in applications such as adsorption, guest exchange, catalysis and chiral separation, magnetic materials, and optical properties. Considerable progress has been achieved in controlling the assembly of individual building blocks into structures with specific topologies and functions. Some structures of MOFs can, to a certain extent, be predicted by exploiting rigid organic ligands, second building units, and elaborately chosen metal salts to control the coordination geometry. However, it is still a challenge to predict the exact structure of assembly products, since the structure is controlled not only by the coordination geometry of the metal ions, the counteranions, the metal-to-ligand ratio, and the solvent system but also by the structural characteristics of polydentate organic ligands. Hence, systematic research on this subject is crucial in understanding the control of structure and topology of MOFs. Among the several factors dominating the design and synthesis of MOFs, it is of great importance to select suitable multidentate ligands. Tripodal ligands with nitrogen donors are a good choice for the construction of supramolecular structures with specific topologies such as individual cagelike structures, dumbbells, and three-dimensional MOFs. For example, rigid or flexible tripodal ligands such as 1,3,5-tricyanobenzene, 1,3,5-tris(4-ethynylbenzonitrile)benzene, 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoate, 1,3,5-tris(p-2,2‘-dipyridylamino)phenylbenzene, 1,3,5-tris(1-imidazolyl)-benzene, 1,3,5-tribenzimidazolyl-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene, 1,3,5-tris[(pyrazol-1-yl)methyl]-2,4,6-triethylbenzene, 1,3,5-tris(4-pyridylmethyl)benzene, and 1,3,5-tris[(benzimidazol-1-yl)methyl]-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene23 have been employed to generate supramolecular structures with metal salts. In contrast to the multiple coordination modes of the flexible tripodal ligands due to their flexibility and low symmetry, which allow the ligands to adopt different conformations according to the geometric needs of different metal ions, the rigid tripodal ligands may have fewer possible coordination modes. According to this approach, we now expand this system with another two novel tripodal ligands, 1,3,5-tris(pyrazol-1-yl)benzene (L1) and 1,3,5-tris[p-(pyraol-1-yl)phenyl]benzene (L2), and silver salts. Three supramolecular networks were obtained and structurally characterized, and the anion exchange properties and fluorescence properties of the complexes were investigated.

elements.content: Preparations of the Ligands and the Complexes. The ligands were synthesized in good yields by the coupling reaction between 1,3,5-tribromobenzene or 1, 3, 5-tri(p-bromophenyl)benzene with excess pyrazole catalyzed by CuI in nitrobenzene with K2CO3 as the base. As shown in Chart , ligand L1 has coordination sites similar to those of the ligands L3  20a and L4. In comparison with ligands L3 and L4, which are substituted by methyl or phenyl at the 2-, 4-, and 6-positions of the central arene rings, L1 has no substitutes at positions 2, 4, and 6; this may have an influence on the construction of the complexes. Complexes 1−3 were prepared in solution by a combination of ligand L with silver salts. Complexes 1 and 2 have a 3:2 ligand to metal composition, and they could also be prepared by mixing the ligand and silver salts directly in solution with stirring (confirmed by IR spectra and powder pattern X-ray diffraction). Considering that the polymeric complexes 1−3 precipitate immediately when the ligands were mixed directly with the silver salts in solution with stirring and the solubilities in common solvents are poor, crystals suitable for X-ray structure analysis can only be obtained by using slow diffusion of the related salts into their ligand solutions.

Results and Disccusion

 Preparations of the Ligands and the Complexes. The ligands were synthesized in good yields by the coupling reaction between 1,3,5-tribromobenzene or 1, 3, 5-tri(p-bromophenyl)benzene with excess pyrazole catalyzed by CuI in nitrobenzene with K2CO3 as the base. As shown in Chart , ligand L1 has coordination sites similar to those of the ligands L3             20a and L4. In comparison with ligands L3 and L4, which are substituted by methyl or phenyl at the 2-, 4-, and 6-positions of the central arene rings, L1 has no substitutes at positions 2, 4, and 6; this may have an influence on the construction of the complexes. Complexes 1-3 were prepared in solution by a combination of ligand L with silver salts. Complexes 1 and 2 have a 3:2 ligand to metal composition, and they could also be prepared by mixing the ligand and silver salts directly in solution with stirring (confirmed by IR spectra and powder pattern X-ray diffraction). Considering that the polymeric complexes 1-3 precipitate immediately when the ligands were mixed directly with the silver salts in solution with stirring and the solubilities in common solvents are poor, crystals suitable for X-ray structure analysis can only be obtained by using slow diffusion of the related salts into their ligand solutions.

elements.content: Crystal Structures of {[Ag 3 L 2 (ClO 4 ) 2 ]ClO 4 } n (1) and {[Ag 3 L 2 (NO 3 ) 2 ]NO 3 } n (2). The fact that the space groups are the same and the cell parameters are similar (Table ) indicates that complex 2 is an isomorph of complex 1. Therefore, only the structure of complex 1 is described in detail. The local coordination environment around the Ag(I) ion in complex 1 is shown in Figure a. X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that each silver(I) atom in 1 is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of pyrazole groups from two ligands and two oxygen atoms from two perchlorates, forming a tetrahedral coordination environment. Each Ag(I) ion links two neighboring ligands and two perchlorates. Each ligand and a perchlorate connect three silver(I) ions together, forming a C 3-symmetrical cage unit (Figure b), and each cage is connected to three neighboring cages by sharing the silver ions, forming a three-dimensional open framework. The silver−silver distance is 5.714(1) Å within a cage. The nitrogen atoms are bound to a silver(I) ion with a normal Ag−N bond length of 2.161(4) Å, whereas perchlorates are weakly bound to the Ag(I) ions through oxygen atoms with an elongated Ag−O bond length of 2.564(6) Å. The bond angles at the silver center deviate from the standard tetrahedron; for example, the bond angles O(1)−Ag−O(1A) and N(1)−Ag−N(1A) are 79.7(5) and 152.6(2)°, respectively. As a consequence, the Ag(I) ion in 1 has a distorted-tetrahedral coordination geometry. There are two kinds of perchlorates in 1:  one is coordinated to silver ions, and the other is free. Three oxygen atoms of the bonded perchlorate connect to three different silver ions, and the fourth oxygen atom is free. The unbonded perchlorates act as counteranions located in the cavities in the structure, as shown in Figure c.

With regard to the Ag3L1 2 network, the silver atom is the two-connecting center, while the ligand serves as a three-coordinate nonplanar node. The whole network can thus be represented topologically by a three-coordinate node and extended to a common (10,3)-a net, as displayed in Figure d. A 10-membered ring is the shortest circuit, and 4-fold helices extend along all of the axes; therefore, the network is chiral. This is the main feature24a of a (10,3)-a net according to Wells.

In complex 2, nitrates replace the positions of perchlorates in complex 1. The details of the structure are not discussed here, and selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in Table .                                                                  

Crystal Structure of {[Ag 4 L 2 2 (NO 3 ) 4 ] · 2CH 3 OH} n (3). As shown in Figure a, the Ag(1) atom is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from each of the two ligands with a normal Ag−N bond length of 2.210(4) Å, the bond angle N(1)−Ag(1)−N(3A) is 164.81(12)°, and atoms N(1), Ag(1), and N(3A) are in a nearly linear arrangement. In addition to this, the Ag(1)−O(4)nitrate, Ag(1)−O(6)nitrate, Ag(1)−O(7)methanol, and Ag(1)−H(15) distances are 2.792(4), 2.734(4), 2.737(5), and 2.684(1) Å, respectively; they may be considered as weak interactions. Ag(2) coordinates to a nitrogen atom from ligand L2 and two oxygen atoms from two nitrates, the Ag(2)−N(5), Ag(2)−O(1), and Ag(2)−O(4) bond distances are 2.267(3), 2.531(4), and 2.438(3) Å, respectively, and the bond angles N(5)−Ag(2)−O(4), N(5)−Ag(2)−O(1), and O(4)−Ag(2)−O(1) are 121.94(11), 133.68(12), and 99.44(11)°, respectively. Additionally, Ag(2) is connected to O(2) and H(23) at longer distances (Ag(2)−O(2) = 2.601(3) Å, Ag(2)−H(23) = 2.670(1) Å). Two organic ligands are connected by two Ag(1) atoms to form a building unit, in which the ligand molecules are parallel to each other with a distance of ca. 3.7 Å and are arranged in a trans configuration. Nitrates bridge the neighboring building units via a weak Ag(1)−O(4)nitrate−Ag(2) interaction, forming a one-dimensional chain which further constructs a three-dimensional framework (Figure b) by hydrogen bonds. The hydrogen bonds consist of the methanol OH group and nitrate with H(7)−O(2) and H(7)−O(3) distances of 2.104(1) and 2.536(1) Å, respectively.

elements.content: The tripodal ligand L1 has coordination sites similar to those of ligands L3  20a and L4. The differences between them are that there are methyl or phenyl substitutes at the 2-, 4-, and 6-positions of the central arene rings in ligands L3 and L4. A cagelike [Ag4L3 4] complex20a and [Ag3L4 2] sandwich structure23b were obtained with L3 and L4. In our case, only polymeric compounds were isolated. It seems that the substituents do not favor the formation of coordination polymeric structures with metal ions. L2 has a larger space group between the coordination sites than does L1; different structures were obtained when the ligands reacted with silver nitrate under the same conditions. The results imply that the structure of the ligand plays a very important role in the formation of the supramolecular construction.

elements.content: Anion-Exchange Properties of Complexes 1 and 2. As demonstrated by the crystal structures of 1 and 2, the counteranions were located in the pores of structures (Figure c). Complexes 1 and 2 are both insoluble in common solvents; therefore, they are expected to display anion-exchange properties. After a suspension of well-ground complex 1 in water with excess NaNO3 was stirred for 24 h at room temperature in the dark, the solid was isolated by filtration, washed with water several times, and dried. The FT-IR spectra of the original 1 and the exchanged solid are recorded. As shown in Figure , intense bands from 1145 to 1077 cm-1, which correspond to the ClO4 - ion, were observed for the original complex 1 (blue). Intense peaks from 1366 to 1343 cm-1 corresponding to the NO3 - ion appeared in the spectrum of the exchanged solid (red), while intense bands from 1145 to 1116 cm-1 related to the free ClO4 - ion disappeared, and the band at 1077 cm-1 corresponding to the coordinated ClO4 - ion is clearly observed. This indicates that the uncoordinated ClO4 - ions exchange with the nitrates. To investigate the reversibility of anion exchange processes in more detail, the exchanged solid was suspended in an aqueous solution of NaClO4 with stirring to allow anion exchange again. The ClO4 - bands from 1145 to 1116 cm-1 reappeared and the NO3 - bands disappeared in the FT-IR spectrum of the re-exchanged solid (green), which is is almost indistinguishable from that of the as-synthesized original complex 1. To further confirm the anion exchange reactions, powder X-ray diffraction techniques were employed to detect the structure of the solids. As shown in Figure , no significant differences were observed between the characteristic peaks of the original 1 (blue), the solid exchanged with NaNO3 (red), and the material re-exchanged with NaClO4 (green). The slight shift and broadening of some peaks may be attributed to incomplete recovery of the symmetry of the structure.
elements.clean_text: Anion-Exchange Properties of Complexes 1 and 2. As demonstrated by the crystal structures of 1 and 2, the counteranions were located in the pores of structures (Figure c). Complexes 1 and 2 are both insoluble in common solvents; therefore, they are expected to display anion-exchange properties. After a suspension of well-ground complex 1 in water with excess NaNO3 was stirred for 24 h at room temperature in the dark, the solid was isolated by filtration, washed with water several times, and dried. The FT-IR spectra of the original 1 and the exchanged solid are recorded. As shown in Figure , intense bands from 1145 to 1077 cm-1, which correspond to  the ClO4 - ion, were observed for the original complex 1 (blue). Intense peaks from 1366 to 1343 cm-1 corresponding to the NO3 - ion appeared in the spectrum of the exchanged solid (red), while intense bands from 1145 to 1116 cm-1 related to the free ClO4 - ion disappeared, and the band at 1077 cm-1 corresponding to the coordinated ClO4 - ion is clearly observed. This indicates that the uncoordinated ClO4 - ions exchange with the nitrates. To investigate the reversibility of anion exchange processes in more detail, the exchanged solid was suspended in an aqueous solution of NaClO4 with stirring to allow anion exchange again. The ClO4 - bands from 1145 to 1116 cm-1 reappeared and the NO3 - bands disappeared in the FT-IR spectrum of the re-exchanged solid (green), which is is almost indistinguishable from that of the as-synthesized original complex 1. To further confirm the anion exchange reactions, powder X-ray diffraction techniques were employed to detect the structure of the solids. As shown in Figure , no significant differences were observed between the characteristic peaks of the original 1 (blue), the solid exchanged with NaNO3 (red), and the material re-exchanged with NaClO4 (green). The slight shift and broadening of some peaks may be attributed to incomplete recovery of the symmetry of the structure.

elements.content: It is very important to confirm that the anion exchanges occur in the solid state or a solvent-related process. 1H NMR experiments were employed to detect whether any of the ligand was dissolved in the mother liquors after the exchange. The mother liquor was extracted with CDCl3; no signal of the ligand was detected in the CDCl3 solutions. Also, no signal of the ligand was observed in the suspensions of the finely ground 1 in CDCl3. The observations imply that the concentration of dissolved ligand in the mother liquor or CDCl3 is too low to be detected by NMR spectroscopy. Furthermore, the concentration of silver ion in the mother liquors after the exchange was measured by using atomic absorption spectroscopy. The solubility of 1 in 0.1 g mL-1 NaClO4 (concentration used in the anion exchange) aqueous solution is 0.0032 mmol L-1. Therefore, the anion exchange reported here is considered to be a solid-state phenomenon. To prove the completion of the exchange, elemental analyses for the exchanged and re-exchanged solids were carried out. The experimental values show good agreement with the calculated values. This indicates that the anion exchanges of 1 occur completely through the whole porous structure and are not just a surface phenomenon.

elements.content: Photoluminescent Properties. Complexes 1−3 are insoluble in common organic solvents; their photoluminescence studies were carried out in the solid state under the same conditions. Solid samples of 1 and 2 show no detectable fluorescence at room temperature. However, an intense emission (λmax at 372 nm) for 3 was observed upon the maximum-excitation wavelength at 285 nm at room temperature (Figure ). The free ligand L2 also displays a fluorescence emission band (λmax at 379 nm on excitation at 354 nm) in the region close to that of 3 (Figure ); the luminescence intensity is much weaker than that of 3. The enhancement and blue shift (7 nm) of the luminescence of 3 compared to that of the free ligand L2 may be attributed to the coordination effect26 of the ligand to the silver ions. The results suggest that the emission of the complex originates from the ligand27 and the photoluminescent properties of ligand L2 can be influenced by the coordination of metal salts.

elements.content: Conclusion. The rigid tripodal nitrogen ligand 1,3,5-tris(pyrazolyl)benzene can react with silver(I) salts to generate two three-dimensional porous supramolecular frameworks which exhibit reversible anion exchange properties without destruction of the structures. The tripodal nitrogen ligand 1,3,5-tris[p-(pyrazol-1-yl)phenyl]benzene, with a large space, reacts with silver nitrate, resulting in a three-dimensional supramolecular network. The results confirmed that the structures of the ligands play a very important role in the construction of the supramolecular structures. The results suggest that the photoluminescence properties of the ligand can be influenced by the coordination of metal salts.

The results suggest that the photoluminescence properties of the ligand can be influenced by the coordination of metal salts.

elements.content: All of the starting materials for the syntheses were obtained commercially (ABCR) and used as received, unless stated otherwise. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Mercury Plus-400 spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported in ppm relative to SiMe4 (δ 0) and were referenced internally with respect to the protio solvent impurity. All coupling constants are reported in Hz. IR spectra were measured as KBr pellets on an Awatar 360-FT spectrophotometer in the range of 4000−400 cm-1. Powder X-ray diffraction pattern studies were carried out on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer. Photoluminescence spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer LS-50B spectrometer. C, H, and N elemental analyses were measured using a Perkin-Elmer 2400 elemental analyzer. The concentrations of silver(I) ion were measured on a Hitachi 180-80 atomic absorption spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All of the starting materials for the syntheses were obtained commercially (ABCR) and used as received, unless stated otherwise. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Mercury Plus-400 spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported in ppm relative to SiMe4 (δ 0) and were referenced internally with respect to the protio solvent impurity. All coupling constants are reported in Hz. IR spectra were measured as KBr pellets on an Awatar 360-FT spectrophotometer in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Powder X-ray diffraction pattern studies were carried out on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer. Photoluminescence spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer LS-50B spectrometer. C, H, and N elemental analyses were measured using a Perkin-Elmer 2400 elemental analyzer. The concentrations of silver(I) ion were measured on a Hitachi 180-80 atomic absorption spectrometer.

elements.content: Synthesis of 1, 3, 5-Tris(pyrazol-1-yl)benzene (L 1 ). 27 A 6.34 g amount (20.0 mmol) of 1,3,5-tribromobenzene, 10.1 g (150 mmol) of pyrazole, 16.6 g (120 mmol) of K2CO3, and 9.90 g (52.0 mmol) of CuI were mixed in 40 mL of nitrobenzene. The mixture was refluxed for 6 h under nitrogen. Then the solid was removed by filtration, the filtrate was collected, and the solvent was removed under vacuum. The crude product was chromatographed on a silica column with light petroleum (bp 60−90 °C)/CH2Cl2 (1:1 v/v) and dried under vacuum. Yield:  4.86 g, 88%. Mp:  144−145 °C (lit. mp 142−144 °C). 1H NMR (CDCl3 at 298 K):  δ 6.62 (t, J = 2.0 Hz, 3 H), 7.76 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 3 H), 8.03 (s, 3 H), 8.08 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 3 H). Anal. Calcd for C15H12N6:  C, 65.21; H, 4.38; N, 30.42. Found:  C, 65.01; H, 4.47; N, 30.52.

elements.content: Anion Exchange for Complexes 1 and 2. A 500 mg portion of NaNO3 was dissolved in water (5 mL), to which 100 mg of well-ground complex 1 was added; this mixture was stirred for 12 h at room temperature in the dark. The solid was isolated by filtration and suspended in water (5 mL); NaNO3 (500 mg) was added, and this mixture was stirred for another 12 h. The solid was isolated by filtration, washed with water several times, and dried. The FT-IR spectrum and the powder pattern X-ray diffraction pattern of the exchanged solid of complex 1 were recorded. Anal. Calcd for C30H24N13Cl2O11Ag3:  C, 31.69; H, 2.13; N, 16.01. Found:  C, 31.63; H, 2.16; N, 16.04. The mother liquors were combined, concentrated to 2 mL, extracted with CDCl3 (3 × 2 mL), and dried with anhydrous MgSO4. The solution in CDCl3 was concentrated to 0.6 mL, and the 1H NMR spectrum was measured. No signal for the ligand was detected. The water phase was diluted to 5 mL, and the concentration of silver ion was measured by using atomic absorption spectrometry. The concentration of silver ion was 0.0032 mmol L-1. The solid was mixed with NaClO4 (500 mg) in water (5 mL) with stirring for 12 h, filtered, and suspended in NaClO4 solution again with stirring for an additional 12 h. The solid was separated by filtration, washed with water several times, and dried. The FT-IR spectrum and the powder pattern X-ray diffraction were determined for the re-exchanged solid of complex 1. Anal. Calcd for C30H24N12Cl3O12Ag3 (1):  C, 30.68, H, 2.06, N, 14.31. Found:  C, 30.62; H, 2.08; N, 14.36. The 1H NMR spectrum of the extracted CDCl3 solution was recorded by following the same procedures as mentioned above, and no signal for the ligand was detected. The concentration of silver ion in the mother liquor was 0.0043 mmol L-1. The anion exchange for complex 2 was carried out by a similar procedure (see the Supporting Information for details).

elements.content: X-ray Crystallographic Data Collection and Refinement. The data crystals were mounted on glass fibers. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements of 1 (0.417 × 0.355 × 0.145 mm), 2 (0.498 × 0.457 × 0.314 mm), and 3 (0.188 × 0.135 × 0.043 mm) were carried out with a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal monochromator for data collection at 293(2) K. Data were collected by the ω/φ scan technique in the ranges 1.90 < θ < 26.980° (for 1), 2.26 < θ < 26.98° (for 2), and 1.59 < θ < 27.00° (for 3). No evidence was detected for crystal decay during data collection of the complexes. All of the measured independent reflections were used in the structural analysis, and empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by using the SHELXTL 97 program. Metal atoms were found from the E maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses. The final refinements were performed by full-matrix least-squares methods with anisotropic thermal parameters for all of the non-hydrogen atoms on F 2. The hydrogen atoms were placed in the calculated sites and included in the final refinement in the riding model approximation, with displacement parameters derived from the parent atoms to which they were bonded. The uncoordinated perchlorate in complex 1 is disordered. A summary of the crystallographic data and structure refinement details is given in Table . Selected bond distances and angles are given in Table .

The ligand L2 was prepared by a method similar to that for L1; the crude product was extracted with hot chloroform and chromatographed on a silica column with CHCl3 as the eluent. Yield: 68%. Mp: 235-237 °C dec. 1H NMR (CDCl3 at 298 K): δ 6.52 (t, J = 2.0 Hz, 3 H), 7.77 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 3 H), 7.81(d, J = 2.4 Hz, 6H), 7.83(d, J = 2.4 Hz, 6H), and 8.00 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 3 H). Anal. cln_elements.content: Photoluminescent Properties. Complexes 1−3 are insoluble in common organic solvents; their photoluminescence studies were carried out in the solid state under the same conditions. Solid samples of 1 and 2 show no detectable fluorescence at room temperature. However, an intense emission (λmax at 372 nm) for 3 was observed upon the maximum-excitation wavelength at 285 nm at room temperature (Figure ). The free ligand L2 also displays a fluorescence emission band (λmax at 379 nm on excitation at 354 nm) in the region close to that of 3 (Figure ); the luminescence intensity is much weaker than that of 3. The enhancement and blue shift (7 nm) of the luminescence of 3 compared to that of the free ligand L2 may be attributed to the coordination effect26 of the ligand to the silver ions. The results suggest that the emission of the complex originates from the ligand27 and the photoluminescent properties of ligand L2 can be influenced by the coordination of metal salts.
